utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Here’s the problem with teleportation.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Lay it on me.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Assuming the device could be invented which would identify the quantum state of matter of an individual in one location, and transmit that pattern to a distant location for reassembly, you would not have actually transported the individual. You would have destroyed him in one location, and recreated him in another.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: How about that.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Personally, I would never use a transporter. Because the original Sheldon would have to be disintegrated in order to create a new Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Would the new Sheldon be in any way an improvement on the old Sheldon?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, he would be exactly the same.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That is a problem.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So, you see it too.

utterance.speaker: Dr Gablehouser (arriving)
utterance.content: Dr Hofstadter, Dr Cooper.

utterance.speaker: Together
utterance.content: Dr Gablehouser.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Gentlemen, I’d like you to meet Dennis Kim. Dennis is a highly sought after Doctorial candidate and we’re hoping to have him do his graduate work here.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Graduate work, very impressive.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: And he’s only fifteen years old.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Not bad, I myself started graduate school at fourteen.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Well, I lost a year while my family was tunnelling out of North Korea.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Advantage Kim.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: I thought maybe you boys could show Dennis around, let him see why we’re the best physics research facility in the country.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: I already know you’re not. You don’t have an open science grid computer, or a free electron laser, and the string theory research being done here is nothing but a dead end.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Excuse me, that is my research, and it is by no means a dead end.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Well, obviously you don’t see it yet, but trust me, you will.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Dennis, we discussed this, we’re in the process of updating our equipment, and we welcome your input on our research goals, and we’ve agreed to look the other way if you want to use up to 20% of the grant money you attract to smuggle your grandfather out of Pyongyang. We want him here boys, make it happen.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes sir.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You can count on us, we’re on it. What the hell do you mean, dead end.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: I mean, the whole landscape of false vacuums in string theory could be as large as ten to the five-hundredth power. In addition… ooh, look, chocolate milk.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I sense a disturbance in the force.

utterance.speaker: Leonard (in a Yoda voice)
utterance.content: A bad feeling I have about this, mmm-hmmm.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, Dennis, how long have you been in America.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: A year and a half.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No kidding, you speak English really well.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: So do you. Except for your tendency to end sentences with prepositions.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What are you talking about?

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: That.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: He’s not wrong. Alright, and this is my office.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Is this part of the tour?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Nope. Goodbye.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on, Sheldon, we’ve hardly shown him anything.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, alright, this is my desk, these are my books, this is my door, please close it behind you. Goodbye.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Looks like you’re doing work in quantum loop corrections.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Keen observation, goodbye.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: You see where you went wrong, don’t you?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Huh, yeah?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Get him out.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on, Dennis, I’ll show you the rec centre, they’ve got nautilus equipment.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Do I look like I lift weights.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Not heavy ones.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: It’s startling to me you haven’t considered a Lorentz invariant field theory approach.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You think I haven’t considered it? You really think I haven’t considered it?

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Have you considered it?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Get him out Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Come on, Dennis, I’ll show you the radiation lab.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Wow, you won the Stephenson award.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, in fact I am the youngest person ever to win it.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Really, how old?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fourteen and a half.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: You were the youngest person ever to win it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s like looking into an obnoxious little mirror, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: Penny (to Raj)
utterance.content: Mmm, this is really delicious, isn’t it? Still can’t talk to me unless you’re drunk, huh? Oh, sweetie, you are so damaged.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey, I’m damaged too. How about a hug for Howie?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sure. Raj, hug Howard.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (dramatically)
utterance.content: Uh-uh-uh.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Something you’d like to share? A tale of woe perhaps.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Fifteen years old. Dennis Kim is fifteen years old, and he’s already correcting my work. Today I went from being Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart to… you know, that other guy.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Antonio Salieri?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, God, now even you’re smarter than me.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You know, Sheldon, you don’t have so many friends that you can afford to start insulting them.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Just eat, Sheldon, you’ll feel better.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Why waste food. In Texas when a cow goes dry they don’t keep feeding it, they just take her out and shoot her between the eyes.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I’m confused, did Sheldon stop giving milk?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You can’t let this kid get to you. You always knew that someday someone would come along who was younger and smarter.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes, but I assumed I would have been dead hundreds of years, and that there would be an asterisk by his name because he would be a cyborg.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: So, you’ve got a bit of competition, I really don’t see what the big deal is.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well of course you don’t, you’ve never excelled at anything.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I don’t understand, exactly how did he get any friends in the first place?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We liked Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, what are you going to do, Sheldon, give up?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes. That’s what a rational person does when his entire life’s work is invalidated by a post-pubescent Asian wunderkind. He ceases his fruitless efforts, he donates his body to scientific research, and he waits to die.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know, I’m confused again, is he waiting, or do we get to shoot him between the eyes?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’ve decided you’re right. My career is not over.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But, since the arrival of Dennis Kim has rendered my research pointless, I just have to find something else to focus on.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: So I’ve decided, I’m going to collaborate with you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Great.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What exactly is it you do? I know you chatter on about it all the time, but I’ve never really paid attention.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, well, right now I’m designing an experiment to study the soft component of cosmic radiation at sea-level, but I really don’t need any help.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, sure you do. Now, see, what’s this here in the schematic, is that a laser array?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No. Hmmm. What happens if you use argon lasers instead of helium neon?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It would blow up.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Are you sure?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Pretty sure.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Pretty sure’s not very scientific, is this how you normally work, just hunches and guesses and stuff?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, Sheldon, I understand that you’re going through a bit of a career crisis, you’re searching for some other area where you can feel valuable and productive but I need to tell you something and I want you to listen carefully.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Alright.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Go away.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: If you’re concerned about sharing credit with me, you’re name can go first… I’m going.

utterance.speaker: Howard (into phone)
utterance.content: It’s a small brown paper bag, Ma, I’m looking at it right now. Why would I make that up, there’s no ding-dong in it. How are two ding-dongs tomorrow going to help me today?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (entering)
utterance.content: So, this is engineering, huh?

utterance.speaker: Howard (into phone)
utterance.content: I’ll talk to you later.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Engineering. Where the noble semi-skilled labourers execute the vision of those who think and dream. Hello, oompah-loompahs of science.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, what are you doing here?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I just came by to say hello.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I’ve been at this lab for three years, you’ve never came by to say hello.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, up until now I’ve had better things to do. So, what are we making today?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: A small payload support structure for a European science experimental package that’s going up on the next space shuttle.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Really, how does it work?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: When this is done, it will be attached to the payload bay, and the sensor apparatus will rest on it.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Uh, huh. So it’s a shelf?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, you don’t understand, during acceleration it needs to stay perfectly level and provide… yeah, okay, it’s a shelf.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Now, I notice you’re using titanium, did you give any consideration to carbon nanotubes, they’re lighter, cheaper and half twice the tensile strength.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon, there’s a diploma in my office that says I have a masters in engineering.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: And you also have a note from your mother that says I love you, bubbula. But neither of those is a cogent argument for titanium over nanotubes.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sheldon.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Go away.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Did Leonard tell you to say that?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, I thought of it all by myself.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Huh. It can’t be a coincidence. There must be some causal link I’m missing.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Go away.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Curiouser and curiouser.

utterance.speaker: Howard (entering)
utterance.content: Is he here?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If he were, I wouldn’t be.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Do you know what he did. He watched me work for ten minutes, and then started to design a simple piece of software that could replace me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Is that even possible?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: As it turns out, yes.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Something’s got to be done about him, Leonard.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Like what? He’ll never be able to cope with the fact that some fifteen year-old kid is smarter and more accomplished than he is.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Well, what if something were to happen to this boy so he was no longer a threat to Sheldon?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Then our problem would be solved.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hang on, are we talking about murdering Dennis Kim? I’m not saying no.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We don’t have to go that far, there are other means available.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: We can’t send him back to North Korea. He knows how to get out.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: The only thing we need to do is make this Kim kid lose his focus.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That won’t happen, he’s not interested in anything but physics.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: What about biology?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You know, biology? The one thing that can completely derail a world class mind.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Howard, he’s fifteen.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, so, when I was fifteen I met Denise Polmerry and my grade point average fell from a 5.0 to a 1.8.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: She was sleeping with you?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, I just wasted a lot of time thinking about what it would be like if she did.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (entering)
utterance.content: Oh, good, you’re all here. Look, I’ve decided that if the three of you drop whatever it is you’re working on and join me, we could lick cold fusion in less than a decade, twelve years tops. Go away? Hmm. Could it be me?

utterance.speaker: Penny (opening door)
utterance.content: Oh, hey guys, what’s up?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: We need a hot fifteen year-old Asian girl with a thing for smart guys.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Howard, that’s racist, any fifteen year-old girl will do the trick.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: It’s possible she may have misunderstood us.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser (entering)
utterance.content: Dr Cooper? Oh, are we interrupting?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: No, no, please, come in. Yeah, I think you’ll appreciate this, very exciting.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Oh, what are you working on?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Something remarkable. Since my prospects for the Nobel Prize in physics have disappeared, thank you very much, I’ve decided to refocus my efforts and use my people skills to win the Nobel Peace Prize. Look, I’m going to solve the Middle-East Crisis by building an exact replica of Jerusalem in the middle of the Mexican desert.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: To what end?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You know, it’s like the baseball movie, build it and they will come.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Who will come?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: The Jewish people.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: What if they don’t come.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We’ll make it nice, put out a spread.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Okay, well, um, speaking of spreads, we’re having a small welcoming party this afternoon for Mr Kim, who’s agreed to join us here at the University.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course he has, the oracle told us little Neo was the one. You can see the Matrix, can’t you.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Okay, well, uh, obviously you’re very busy with your… uh, um, come Dennis. You’ll have to excuse Dr Cooper, he’s been under a lot of… um… he’s nuts.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (voice off, sings to a Mexican tune)
utterance.content: Ah, la-la-la, Hava Nagila. They’ll come, they’ll settle and I’ll win the prize…

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I really don’t understand your objections, Professor Goldfarb, why wouldn’t the Senoran Desert make a perfectly good promised land?

utterance.speaker: Goldfarb
utterance.content: Go away.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: We could call it Nuevo Cherusalem.

utterance.speaker: Goldfarb
utterance.content: Please go away.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Said Pharoah to Moses.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Why are all these young women here?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It’s take your daughter to work day.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Really, I was not aware of that.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Oh, yes. There was a very official email that was sent to everyone whose insurance files indicated they had daughters between the ages of 14 and 16.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Hm?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Smooth.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: There’s the man of the hour.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, so we now have a socially awkward genius in a room full of attractive age-appropriate women.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: All he has to do now is hook up with one of them.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Does anyone else see the flaw in this plan?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: We need a social catalyst.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Like what? We can’t get fifteen year-old girls drunk.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Or can we?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, we can’t.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I don’t think you mean we can’t. I think you mean we shouldn’t.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Hey, Howard. You’re a Jew. If there was another wailing wall, exactly like the one in Jerusalem, but close to taco stands and cheap prescription drugs, would you still be able to wail at it? Okay, it’s definitely me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, we cannot leave this to chance, lets pick a girl, and figure out how to get her together with Dennis.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay. How about that one.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Uh-uh. I know the type, cheerleader, student council, goes out with jocks, won’t even look at anybody in the gifted programme. And if, after two years of begging, she does agree to go out with you, it turns out to be a set-up and you’re in the back seat of your mom’s car with your pants off while the whole football team laughs at you.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Are you crying?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: No, I have allergies.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, uh, how about her?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Sure. If he wants to spend a couple of years doing her homework while she drinks herself into a stupor with non-fat White Russians, while you’re the one holding her head out of the toilet while she’s puking and telling you she wishes more guys were like you, and they she gets into Cornell because you wrote her essay for her, and you drive up to visit her one weekend and she acts like she doesn’t even know you.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Okay, so not her either. How about her?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Interesting, kind of pretty, a little chubby so probably low self-esteem.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I think that’s our girl. One of us should go talk to her.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I can’t talk to her, you do it.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I can’t just go up and talk to her. Howard, you talk to her.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Oh no, she’ll never go for the kid once she gets a peek at this.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You know, if we were in India this would be simpler. Five minutes with her dad, twenty goats and a laptop and we’d be done.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, we’re not in India.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Alright, why don’t we do it your way then? We’ll arrange for this girl to move in across the hall from Dennis so he can pathetically moon over her for months on end.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, that was uncalled for.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You started it, dude.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Could I have everyone’s attention please. What a wonderful occasion this is. And how fortunate that it should happen to fall on take your daughter to work day. We’re here to welcome Mr Dennis Kim to our little family.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (sarcastically)
utterance.content: Welcome Dennis Kim.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Mr Kim was not only the valedictorian at Stamford University, he is also the youngest recipient of the prestigious Stephenson Award.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Youngest till the cyborgs rise up!

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: And now, without any further ado, let me introduce the man of the hour, Mr Dennis Kim. Dennis! Dennis!

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Would you like to tell us a little bit about your upcoming research.

utterance.speaker: Dennis
utterance.content: Um, no thanks. I’m going to the mall with Emma.

utterance.speaker: Gablehouser
utterance.content: Well, uh, well, uh….

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: The kid got a girl.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Unbelievable.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Did anyone see how he did it?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon (to Gablehouser)
utterance.content: Don’t worry, I’ve got this. Ladies and Gentlemen, honoured daughters. While Mr Kim, by virtue of his youth and naivety, has fallen prey to the inexplicable need for human contact, let me step in and assure you that my research will go on uninterrupted, and that social relationships will continue to baffle and repulse me. Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: He’s back.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, mission accomplished.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Forget the mission, how did that little yutz get a girl on his own?

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I guess times have changed since we were young. Smart is the new sexy.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Well, why do we go home alone every night, we’re still smart.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Maybe we’re too smart. So smart it’s offputting.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yeah, let’s go with that.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Unbelievable. Components I built are on the International Space Station, and I get a ticket for launching a model rocket in the park.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know if the ticket was so much for the launch as it was for you telling the policewoman “you have to frisk me, I have a rocket in my pants.”

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, look at that. It’s Dennis Kim.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Wow, I almost didn’t recognise him.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: You know, I kind of feel bad about what we did to him.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, we really ruined his life.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Screw him, he was weak.
